conclusion: Determine the increase in the range of light incident on the central point at the bottom of the light-transmitting hole with a glass brick embedded.
The diameter of the circular light hole is L = 40 cm and the thickness is d = 20√3 cm.
Calculate the initial angle of incidence i0 without the glass brick: i0 = 30°.
A glass brick with a refractive index n = √3 is embedded in the light hole.
Use Snell's law to find the angle of refraction r in the glass: r = 30°.
Calculate the angle of incidence i in the air for which the light will refract at r = 30°: i = 90°.
Determine the increase in the range of incidence: 90° - 30° = 60°.
The range of light incident on the central point at the bottom of the light-transmitting hole is increased by 60° compared to that before embedding the glass brick.
